faqA1: Yes. Sterile, single-use needles are used for each donor, eliminating any risk of infection.
faqA2: Whole blood donors can donate every 8 weeks (56 days). Platelet or plasma intervals differ.
faqA3: Most donors feel fine. Your body replaces the lost fluid within 24 hours and red cells within weeks.
faqQ4: Can I donate if I have a tattoo?
faqA4: If your tattoo was done at a licensed facility using sterile equipment, you can donate after 3 months.
faqQ5: How long does the donation take?
faqA5: The actual blood draw is 8-10 minutes; the full visit takes about an hour including screening and rest.
faqQ6: What if I have traveled recently?
faqA6: Some regions with malaria or other risks may defer you temporarily. Screening staff will advise.
faqQ7: Do I need to know my blood type first?
faqA7: No. We will type your blood after donation and let you know the result.
faqQ8: Can I donate if I take medication?
faqA8: Most common medications are fine. Bring a list; staff will confirm your eligibility.

healthRequirement: No major illness or infection in the past 2 weeks
intervalRequirement: At least 8 weeks since last whole blood donation

registrationDesc: Complete a quick registration form with your basic information and medical history.
healthScreeningDesc: A healthcare professional will check your temperature, blood pressure, pulse, and hemoglobin levels.
